column10: This RHoMIS application took place within the setting of a gender action program led by CIMMYT, funded by the CGIAR CCAFS program. It aimed at evaluating a Gender Action Learning System (GALS) intervention in two locations close to Lilongwe.

column10: The SAIRLA project, led by Bioversity International was executed in Ethiopia, Kenya and Tanzania to work with farmers to sustainably intensify their production. column10: The CLiP project, led by IITA and ILRI is executed in the Democratic Republic of Congo and Burundi. The project focuses on promoting sustainable interventions improving the efficiency of crop - livestock interactions in the mixed systems of these countries. A RHoMIS baseline survey was executed in both countries to characterize the current production systems, the existing adoption of crop-livestock production intensification management options and to assess livelihood welfare in the different regions.

column10: This exercise was part of the impact evaluation of the Accelerated Value Chains for Dairy (AVCD) project funded by USAID aiming, as the title suggests, at value chain development for dairy cattle produce. The RHoMIS application was a bit of a side exercise to the major impact evaluation survey that was executed, where the RHoMIS application was aimed at generating more detailed farm and livelihood information than the large IA survey.
column15: Homa Bay, Kisumu, Migori, Siaya, Vihiga
column16: Respondents were selected through a two-stage, stratified cluster random sampling, one at the ward level and the other at the household level for each county. A random sample of wards is selected with probability proportional to the size of the population and number of households in each ward relative to the total population in all the wards in the counties. The wards are selected randomly from a list of all wards in the counties. The counties represent the strata and when a ward is selected, all the households within the ward are also automatically selected, as in cluster sampling. For this study, a total of 169 households were selected as the representative sample from all the six counties in Western Kenya.
column18: Counties of Homa Bay, Kisumu, Migori, Siaya and Vihiga
column24: Core, Livestock Feeding, Cattle - detailed, HFIAS

column10: In this project in Ethiopia TreeAID is promoting the sustainable use of environmental resources, and then especially the use of fire wood. A RHoMIS baseline survey was executed in the central highlands of Ethiopia to characterize the current production systems, the existing use of environmental resources and the role the latter play in the livelihood of the smallholder farmers.
column16:
In total 380 households were interviewed in the region north of Meki. Subsistence oriented households were randomly sampled from the available village lists obtained from the village elderly.

This baseline was not restricted to the beneficiaries (as there were unknown delays in beneficiary selection) so we sampled from the whole population of the project area. The project will work with approximately half the population of the area and therefore for analysis we divided the population into quartiles. As long as beneficiary selection is targeted to the poorer community members (which is the idea of the project) then the lower two quartiles shown the baseline report will be representative of the project beneficiaries.
column18: Production systems of subsistence oriented farmers in the Meki region
column20: The survey was executed as a baseline to characterize the existing livelihoods and their use of environmental resources
column24: Core, Forest Products, HFIAS, Changes on Farm
column33: Meki_v2; EB3; plus a smaller survey from EB1

column10:
This study was both a baseline and an evaluation as the UKAM project was built to further develop on a previous project. We sampled from within two groups, previous beneficiaries (who were also going to be part of the new project) and future beneficiaries, those who had not had any previous project support but who were earmarked to. So while baselining everyone we were also able to have a control group to compare the previous beneficiaries to and evaluate impact against those who had not had support.
The results were really interesting and are actually being written up into a Climate Smart Agriculture book chapter, led by Jim (the rhomis developer),

column10:
To support the community to build upon previous work completed in developing participatory Forest Management Plans. Over three years, the project successfully protected and restored 11,619 hectares of forest through a series of best practice Natural Resource Management (NRM) techniques, planting of indigenous tree species, and building the capacity of local communities and authorities to effectively manage the two forests. 

The project also supported the communities to set up 44 small-scale enterprises (known as Village Tree Enterprises) based on Non Timber Forest Products (NTFPs) to improve livelihoods and increase incomes, focusing primarily on shea and honey value chains. The project also worked with two existing local cooperatives, Farakunna and Hirosin, to increase their support for their members and the communities, as well as their stewardship of the local forest resources.
column16: Interviews with 363 households were conducted. Informants were selected randomly from 21 villages within the project area. The villages were selected according to already established relationships with partner organisations.

column10: The GALVMED ITM4Impact project was executed to quantify the herd, farm and livelihood effects of the cattle vaccine against East Coast Fever, known as ITM, in smallholder livestock-keeping farm households in Tanzania.
column16: Out of 270 animal health service providers for whom contacts had been collected throughout the country, 119 were randomly selecting, focusing on those active in areas with high cattle density and categorised by their distributing the vaccine against East Coast Fever. Each of these were requested to list farmers they were serving, categorising them by whether and how long they had adopted the vaccine and by production system. Out of these listed farmers, 994 were randomly selected, stratified by vaccine uptake and production system, and interviewed.
column18: Livestock holders in Tanzania, engaged with animal health service providers
column20: The survey was executed to evaluate possible positive effects on herd and farm productivity as well as household livelihood.
column24: Core, herd composition, vaccination and other livestock inputs
column26: Expanded livestock holdings, animal health implementation.

column8: Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR), Institut National pour l’Etude et la Recherche Agronomique (INERA), Université de Kisangani (UNIKIS)
column9: The Formation, Recherche, Envrionment dans la Tshopo (FORETS) project
column10: The FORETS project, led by ICRAF was executed in Democratic Republic of Congo. The project focused on promoting sustainable use of forest resources in the neighbourhood of the Yangambi Biosphere Reserve.
column16: 413 households were interviewed along the main axes surrounding the Yangambi Biosphere Reserve. One axe runs along the Western and Southern edge of the reserve radiating from the Southwest Corner where the Yangambi Research Station sits (N=243 households). The other axes run from the northeast along the northern edge of the reserve in particular the Yangambi Weko axis to the west (243) and Bengamisa-Weko (170) to the north, both areas of deforestation and encroachment. The three-stage sampling procedure included purposeful sampling (used to equitably select households along the two major axes) and random sampling based on population sizes (established by development plans) and on the population in the village
column18: Yangambi region, indicative of households living at forest margin in Central Africa
column24: Core, Coping Strategies, Food Consumpstion Score, WASH, Expenditures, Forest Products, Slash and Burn

column10: The SCAN project, led by ICRAF was executed in Kenya and Zambia. The project focused on promoting climate smart agricultural production interventions. A RHoMIS baseline survey was executed in both Kenya and Zambia to characterize the current production systems, the existing adoption of climate smart practices and to assess livelihood welfare in the different production systems.
column16: In total 385 households were interviewed in the Kitui and Baringo regions. Baringo and Kitui Counties were selected to differ in agroecological zone and livelihood strategies. In both Baringo and Kitui, four divisions were purposefully selected based on population density. Two of the four were randomly selected. Within each division, two sub-locations were purposefully selected to capture economic and geographic heterogeneity. Forty to sisty households were randomly selected to participate in each sublocation.
column18: Production systems in the Baringo and Kitui regions
column20: The survey was executed to look at the pathways among climate, agriculture and nutrition (measured as the proxy dietary diversity).

column16: Interviewed farmersbelong to the 73 farmers having participated at least once to our collective activities on co-design in 2017 (1 workshop and 2 field days). In 2 community, a contact person was tasked with inviting between 20 and 30 farmers representing a wide range of local farming systems and demographics (low and high resource endowed farmers; cotton farmers, herders and farmers-herders; young and old; male and female) to the  workshop and field days.

column10: Grain Legumes and Dry Land Crops, CRP
column16: First, one district was selected within the Drylands Development (DryDev) program intervention zone in each country. The selected districts were Zogoré, Burkina Faso; Yorosso, Mali; and Droum, Niger. Six villages were chosen from each district for the second stage of sampling. An additional two  villages in each district were selected as non-beneficiary sites where DryDev undertook no interventions. A total of 24 villages were surveyed. At the third stage of sampling, the household was identified as the unit of analysis. A total of 600 respondents, 25 respondents per village were randomly selected.

column10: In this project in Ethiopia TreeAID is promoting the sustainable use of environmental resources. A RHoMIS survey was executed in the central highlands of Ethiopia to characterize the current production systems, the existing use of environmental (and more specifically forest) resources and the role the latter play in the livelihood of the smallholder farmers.
column16:
Survey divided into two sample groups.
(a) EA3 is targetting 2501 beneficiaries. Of these 1716 are named Co-Op members, and 1622 are VTE members - named records were not available at time of Rhomis Survey (Spring 2018). Overlap between Co-Op and VTE membership has now been established, please see Beneficiary List. Additional 100 named VTE members named in three adjacent non-forested Kebels. In total, from this group Rhomis is sampling 271 (Confidence: 90%; Margin of Error: 5%)
(b) The EB5 project proposal includes 2x new kebeles in which there are 4x new gots: Total hh: 887. It was decided not to sample at Confidence 90%/Error 5% as this gave a sample size of 30% of population. This was deemed to be intrusive and high risk in raising expectations. Instead, the sample size was taken at 15% of households across the 4x Gots, with a weighted distribution between Gots. Total number of hh: 133 (This equates to a Confidence Level of 78.7%; Margin of Error: 5%.)

Final Survey Respondants were: 244 (60.2%) Existing Beneficiaries; 161 (30.8%) Non/New Beneficiaries.
column18: Production systems of subsistence oriented farmers in the sub-regions surveyed
column20: Two components (a) Endline for Eth-115 (EA3) project; (b) context analysis for 4x new Gots /2x new Kebeles to be included in the extension/scale up EB5 proposal (UK AID Direct)

column10: The Dugda-Meki Natural Resource Conservation and Livelihoods Enhancement Project aims to contribute to create a healthy ecosystem and alleviate poverty in the Central Rift Valley of Ethiopia. TREE AID and its partner will work with local communities to decrease dependency and pressure on the natural resources and enhance sustainable livelihoods. The project will support the restoration of degraded lands and increase vegetation by the creation of 9 enclosures areas, while increase the dietary diversity and income of 3,584 people and their households. 24 enterprises groups will be created based on the production and commercialisation of vegetable, fruits, honey and fuel saving stoves. All the beneficiaries (3,584) will received nutritional training and food trees in order to improve their household diet.

column10:
To contribute to the sustainable reduction in the number of smallholders farmers in the Northern region in Ghana living below the poverty line. The project will work directly with 3,000 poor smallholder cashew farmers and 600 additional women and young men, and
indirectly with about 14,400 people in Ghana’s Northern Region, to increase and diversify incomes. We aim to improve
cashew yields with intercropped legumes (nitrogen fixing) and honey production (increased pollination), alongside
developing 150 VTEs and one Cooperative Union. Cashew farmers will acquire skills in silviculture and agriculture to
improve cashew production.
column16: Baseline for Project. Respondents randomly sampled from the Beneficiary List. Also included 24 hh as a control group from Sawla Tuna Kalba (district).

column10: Rehabilitate the ecosystem and enhance community-level economic development in the Nigerien area of the W trans-boundary biosphere reserve (WTBR/Niger) which is composed of Park W and its periphery. Through effective community forest governance, the development of partnerships between the local communities and Park W management, and tree-related enterprise development, the project will protect threatened biodiversity while enhancing local livelihoods. The project is responding to a lack of interventions promoting sustainable resource management in the peripheral area.

column10: The project involved trialling of various new breeds of cassava, as well as development of cassava value chains and processing options. The survey was a combination of a 1000 minds questionaire among cassava farmers, processors and marketers to determine the relative importance of a set of user preffered traits. Furthermore the survey also included farmers that are part of a TRICOT (320 fields over 4 states in Nigeria) experiment. Part of the 1000 mind respondents overlapped with the TRICOT respondents.

column10: LegumeSELECT project aims to increase the contribution of legumes to smallholder livelihoods through more appropriate legume selection decisions. The project will achieve this by further developing the existing decision support framework 'LegumeCHOICE' by combining existing data with new data from experimentation to resolve legume traits, and evaluation of individual farm biophysical and socioeconomic contexts. This will provide knowledge and tools to aid smallholder farmers in making rational decisions for smart integration and use of multi-purpose legumes for an enhanced production environment.

column10: Project works towards improving the economic and social status for 1,000 women in the Koulikoro region of Mali through greater forest access rights, management responsibility and participation in enterprises.
column16:
Sampled from the Project Beneficiary List. Raosoft: 90% Confidence/5% Margin Error. Ephasis on sampling from HH level, rather than individual beneficiary level. Beneficiary List shows 1017 Beneficiaries, across 692 hh.
Removed 82 individuals who have a Chef de Ménages with more than 4 project beneficiaries in their household. Listed 514 individuals who have a Chef de Ménages with only one project beneficiary per household. Include all in the list to be sampled from. Listed 248 individuals who have a Chef de Ménages with TWO project beneficiaries per household. Include one of each pair (124) in the list to be sampled from. Listed 126 individuals who have a Chef de Ménages with THREE project beneficiaries per household. Include one of each set of three (42) in the list to be sampled from. Listed 48 individuals who have a Chef de Ménages with FOUR project beneficiaries per household. Include one of each set of four (12) in the list to be sampled from. This gives a total list of 692 households to sample from. Raosoft advises a sample of 195hh (Confidence 90%; Margin of Error 5%) + 10% = 216 Households. Generate 216 Random Integers between 1 and 692; replace duplicates with +1. Apply the 216 random integers to the Total List of 692 households to sample from. Update Beneficiary List with 216 HH sampled for the RHoMIS baseline.

column10:
To support the community to build upon previous work completed in developing participatory Forest Management Plans. Over three years, the project successfully protected and restored 11,619 hectares of forest through a series of best practice Natural Resource Management (NRM) techniques, planting of indigenous tree species, and building the capacity of local communities and authorities to effectively manage the two forests. 

The project also supported the communities to set up 44 small-scale enterprises (known as Village Tree Enterprises) based on Non Timber Forest Products (NTFPs) to improve livelihoods and increase incomes, focusing primarily on shea and honey value chains. The project also worked with two existing local cooperatives, Farakunna and Hirosin, to increase their support for their members and the communities, as well as their stewardship of the local forest resources.

column16: Simple random sampling technique was employed to select 400 farmers from each district. Out of the 400 farmers in each district, 200 were selected from the CSVs (treatment group) and the remaining 200 from villages with similar agroecological condition except for the involvement of households in the CSA practices (the control group). By comparing outcomes between the treated and untreated households, it can be possible to assess the impacts of the treatment (the CSA practices) on agricultural production, income, food security and food diversity.

column10: The Livestock CRP priority country project in Vietnam aims at stimulating system transformation (livelihoods, environment, equity, and market access) to empower highland farming communities through bundled livestock-based interventions in the North-West highlands. The project, short-named “Li-chăn”, which means “livestock is good” in local language, is characterized by a system and landscape approach, a focus on multiple species (large ruminants and local pigs), and community-based activities in agreement with government plans. The project started in 2020.
column16: 2 treatment communes selected by project, 8 characterisation communes randomly selected within Mai Son district (these include 2 communes similar to the treatment communes which will serve as controls).  Only households raising cattle and/or pigs
